content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Diabetes Self-Management Training Act of 2007". The findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that diabetes is a major public health threat in the US, with 21 million people currently living with diabetes and 54 million with pre-diabetes. Diabetes is the 6th leading cause of death, with the prevalence of the most common type tripling in the last 30 years. Approximately 2,200 people are diagnosed with diabetes daily. Diabetes self-management training is crucial for patients to identify barriers and acquire necessary skills and knowledge. Diabetes self-management training, also known as diabetes education, provides essential knowledge and skills to help patients effectively manage their diabetes. Certified diabetes educators, such as nurses, dietitians, or pharmacists, specialize in assisting individuals with diabetes in developing self-management skills to prevent complications and secondary conditions. This training has been proven effective in reducing the risks associated with diabetes. Diabetes self-management training has been proven effective in reducing the risks and complications of diabetes. Lifestyle changes can significantly reduce the risk of developing type 2 diabetes, especially in older individuals. Patients under the care of a certified diabetes educator show better control of their condition. Studies have shown that diabetes self-management training, particularly effective in individuals aged 60 and older, can reduce the development of diabetes by 71%. Patients under the care of certified diabetes educators demonstrate better control of their condition, leading to improved health outcomes. Lifestyle changes taught by educators contribute to better glycemic control and reduced complications from diabetes, with the potential for preventing serious medical complications being as high as 90% for blindness, 85% for amputations, and 50% for heart disease and stroke. There are over 20,000 diabetes educators in the US, most certified by the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators. Certification requires specific healthcare credentials, practice experience, passing an exam, and periodic renewal. Diabetes educators certified by the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators, and licensed by a State as a health professional, have extensive experience in diabetes self-management training and are qualified to provide such training under the Medicare program. Certified diabetes educators recognized as certified providers for Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. Certified diabetes educators are now recognized as certified providers for Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. The term 'certified diabetes educator' refers to a licensed health care professional specializing in teaching individuals with diabetes to manage their condition, certified by a recognized certifying body. Certified diabetes educators are licensed health care professionals specializing in teaching individuals with diabetes to manage their condition. They must be certified by a recognized certifying body, such as the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators, to provide Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. The National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators or a certifying body for diabetes educators must meet specific requirements for certification, including having a qualifying credential in a healthcare profession and professional practice experience in diabetes self-management training. The National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators or a certifying body for diabetes educators must meet specific requirements for certification, including having a qualifying credential in a healthcare profession, professional practice experience in diabetes self-management training, completing a national certification examination, and renewing certification periodically. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to identify barriers for Medicare beneficiaries with diabetes in accessing diabetes care. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to identify barriers for Medicare beneficiaries with diabetes in accessing diabetes self-management training services under the Medicare program. The study will focus on economic and geographic barriers, availability of referrals, and access to qualified providers. Additionally, the Director of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will develop recommendations for outreach methods and submit a report to Congress within one year. The Director of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will develop recommendations on effective outreach methods for educating primary care physicians and the public about the benefits of diabetes self-management training. A report on these recommendations must be submitted to Congress within one year. Healthcare Research and Quality will report to Congress on recommendations for diabetes outpatient self-management training services. The amendments will apply to services provided six months after the enactment of the Act.
